metadata.description: Allocation of primary energy sources to end-use sectors, based on IEA World Energy Balances
metadata.methodology: Weighted average allocation derived from IEA energy flow data (2019-2024)
sources: IEA Energy Statistics Manual - Flow methodology
metadata.key_insight: Oil is 90% transport (high-exergy mechanical), gas is 60% low-temp heating (low-exergy), renewables are 100% electricity (high-exergy)

oil.notes: Dominated by road transport, aviation, shipping. Minimal heating oil remaining in developed countries.

gas.notes: 40% used in combined-cycle power plants (high efficiency). 50% residential/commercial heating (low exergy). 10% industrial process heat.

coal.notes: Primarily used for power generation and steel/cement production (high-temperature processes).

nuclear.notes: 100% used for electricity generation. Includes 3% grid balancing/storage losses.

hydro.notes: 100% electricity generation (run-of-river and reservoir-based). Includes 3% pumped storage losses.

wind.notes: 100% electricity generation (onshore and offshore turbines). Includes 5% battery storage losses.

solar.notes: 95% solar PV for electricity. 5% solar thermal for water heating. Includes 5% battery storage losses for PV.

biomass.notes: 70% traditional biomass (cooking, heating in developing countries - very low efficiency). 15% modern biofuels (transport). 10% biomass power. 5% industrial.

geothermal.notes: 50/50 split between binary cycle power plants and direct-use heating applications.

electricity_generation.description: All electricity has maximum exergy quality

calculation_example.description: How to calculate energy services from primary energy
steps: Step 1: Primary Energy (EJ) - from OWID data
Step 2: Useful Energy = Primary × Efficiency Factor (from efficiency_factors_corrected.json)
Step 3: Allocate to sectors using source_sector_allocation percentages
Or simplified: Energy Services = Useful Energy × Weighted_Exergy_Factor

example_coal.interpretation: Coal's useful energy of 32% reduces to 27.8% services due to 30% allocation to heat (low exergy)

example_wind.interpretation: Wind's useful energy equals services because 100% is electricity (maximum exergy)

example_gas.interpretation: Gas's useful energy of 45% reduces to 25.2% services because 50% goes to low-temp heating (exergy penalty)

validation_targets.global_2024_services: ~118-125 EJ (Brockway et al. 2019 baseline ~100 EJ for 2015, expect ~120 EJ for 2024 with growth)
validation_targets.global_exergy_efficiency: ~20% (revised with stricter low-temp exergy 0.15 and storage losses)
validation_targets.calculation: Global services = (Σ Useful Energy × Weighted Exergy) ≈ 620 EJ primary × 0.33 useful eff × 0.60 exergy ≈ 123 EJ
validation_targets.brockway_reference: Brockway et al. 2019 - Exergy chains analysis, estimated ~100 EJ global services for 2015
validation_targets.storage_losses_note: Clean electricity includes 5% storage/balancing losses (wind 0.95, solar 0.91, hydro 0.97, nuclear 0.97)
